  • LIFELOGGING launch party

    Last Thursday I attended the launch party for the [Science Gallery’s][1] upcoming exhibition entitled [#LIFELOGGING.][2]   Let me first put this into context. The science gallery is one of my favourite museums in the world, and definetly one of my favourite places in Dublin. It manages to put together great show s where art and science not only mix, but fades together for three months. A truly collaborative enriching experience for both disciplines. This exhibition is my favourite so far, and I wrote about it for my friends at [THE ISSUE][3]. Read the full entry on their website!

    In the last two posts about the recsys challenge  ([part][1] I and [part II][2]) I have discussed in detail some aspects of this year’s challenge data. This time I present an analysis of the data from the point of view of categories and the role they play in clicks, sessions and buys.

  • On what comes after us

    Pictures of you are still hanging on the wall.
    I am not ready to change from lovers to whatever is next
    Sometimes I miss you and sometimes I don’t, all in the same day. 

     I don’t know what to say,
    neither how to shut up
    and i     definitely don’t want to hurt you.

    • Read more

  • On my inhibition when speaking

    There was  a time where we could speak clear.
    I used to tell you almost everything.
    Words would flow from my brain to my mouth without a filter,
    Now a big filter keeps me from even speaking,
    mainly because I loved you. Sometimes because I was sad, happy or angry.
    it is there to protect you, protect me, and because it has to be like this.

    • Read more

  • A weekend of art in London

    A day in London can start in countless ways. Mine started being woken up by a guy snoring in the bunk-bed next to mine on a cheap hostel near South Kensington; the perks of low budget accommodation! However, things turned on my side very soon when I left my bed, quickly dressed up and started exploring the streets of this beautiful neighbourhood where you find all the cool shops where you can’t afford buying anything.

A retrospective about the irish painter and architect [Patrick Scott][2].  I admit this is my favourite exhibition at the museum so far, and I am lucky because I discovered an irish gem, an unknown artist for me which surprised me greatly.

Almost every decent office business in the world has a [Barcelona chair][3], a timeless piece originally designed in 1929.

  • Dallas Green, City and Colour

    Puedo decir sin miedo a ser juzgado que Dallas Green es un genio de la música. Después de pasar  diez años  con [Alexisonfire][1], en 2011 decidió que City and Colour – hasta entonces su proyecto paralelo –  tenía que ser el eje principal de su carrera y el resultado ha sido increíble,  un disco titulado Little Hell que muestra una clara evolución de su estilo y una gira que lo ha llevado por EEUU, Canadá (su país de origen) y toda Europa.

    • Read more

  • McGinley, Ryan.

    Ryan McGinley (1977, Nueva Jersey) es probablemente mi fotógrafo favorito, sus trabajos desprenden una energía, naturalidad y captan la juventud y frescura de forma que rara vez se ve y además es un fotógrafo muy joven que aún tiene mucho que ofrecernos.

  • Polaroid, ?

    En 1948 Edwin Land lanzaba su primera cámara instantánea en la empresa “polaroid corporation” , esta y muchas otras fueron un éxito, pero en 2001 la polaroid corporation se declaró en bancarrota. En parte la mala gestión (Mr. Land murió en 1991) , y en parte la evolución del mercado empujado por la fotografía digital llevaron a que la compañía fuese comprada por otra que siguió usando tanto el nombre comercial como el corporativo. En 2008 se dejaron de vender cámaras polaroid (después de una nueva bancarrota) y en 2009 se dejó de vender el film. La nueva empresa que comercializa POLAROID poco tiene que ver con la compañía original – y sus productos (que han sido desastre tras desastre) lo demuestran!

    • Read more
